transcripts.original_text: I Darius Branch, of Castleton in the County of Rutland, and State of Vermont, testify and say, that I was living with my Father in the south east part of Bennington in the fall of the year 1782, near the residence of Capt. Jonathan Scott, and was present at his house in the early part of September, (as I think,) and say Samuel Holmes and Sallena Scott united in marriage by Moses Robinson, Esq. I cannot recollect the precise day of the month, but distinctly remember that there was a party of tories discovered going through a pasture in the easterly part of Bennington, which caused the inhabitants to suspect that all was not right; the alarm was immediately given to my Father and others, and a Company of men raised who went in pursuit, and after pursuing them about eight miles, captured them on the Green Mountain, I think twelve in number, with a Capt. Blakeslee and a negro man whom the tories had taken and were carrying off or leading off to Canada; I was too young to be one of the pursuers, being now in my twenty eight year, but am confident that Samuel Holmes was one of the party; I was present at the house of Gen. Samuel Safford and saw the Tories when they were brought in by our Troops; I was intimately acquaint-

No 1
State of New York
Genesee County:
On this seventeenth day of June in the year 1842, personally appeared before the Court of Common Pleas of the said county of Genesee Betsey Holmes a resident of the town of Attica in the county of Wyoming and State of New York aged eighty two years, who being first duly sworn according to law on her oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the provision made by the Act of Congress passed July 4, 1836.
That she is the widow of Moses Holmes, who was an assistant commissary in the Revolutionary war and served during the war for which he enlisted, but the particulars of his service she cannot particularly state and she refers to his Pension Declaration under the Act of the 7th June 1832 and the papers accompanying the same for proof of his services.
She further states that her late husband , Moses Holmes, in a recent application for an increase of pension has set forth his services only for the term of four years, as he had been informed and believed that two years service only was necessary to be set forth in order to secure an increase of his pension, when in truth this declarant believes and knows that he served for a longer period and as she believes for and during the war.
She further declares that she was married to the said Moses Holmes on the first day of June in the year one thousand and seven hundred and eighty, that her husband the aforesaid Moses Holmes died on the twenty fourth day of April last part and that she has remained a widow ever since that period, as will more fully appear by reference to the

Tioga County

She further declares that she was married to the said Moses Holmes on the first day of June in the year one thousand seven hundred and eighty, that her husband the aforesaid Moses Holmes died on the twenty fourth day of April last past and that she has remained a widow ever since that period, as will more fully appear by reference to the

Commonwealth of Massachusetts.
County of Worcester, ss.
ON this sixth day of September in the year of our Lord, eighteen hundred and thirty two personally appeared in open Court, before Hon. Nathl Paine, Judge of that Court of Probate now sitting Jonathan Howe, a resident of Paxton, in the County of Worcester, and Commonwealth of Massachusetts, aged seventy years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress, passed June 7th, 1832.
THAT he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated.
That he was born 30 Sept. 1761, in that part of Rutland, now Paxton, where he has resided ever since.
That in the autumn of 1777, his father, Paul Howe, now deceased, enlisted for seven months in this (cause) of the Revolution, & went to Springfield, Mass. at the expiration of one month. After he had been transferred to Brookfield, Mass. he, the abovenamed Jonathan Howe, at his father's request, on account of his ill health, took his place as his substitute at said Brookfield, and there performed a term of service of six months, in (defense) of (the) military (stores) deposited at that place. The only duty performed was to stand sentry, which he faithfully performed for the above stated term, at the expiration of which time he was honorably dismissed. The officers who had command of the troops stationed at said Brookfield during that term, were Lieut. Peter Davis of Rutland, and Lieut. Freeman, of Sturbridge. Tilly Chaffin, now of Holden, was with him in the same service during (the) said term; Levi Hathaway, of North Brookfield, was with him a part of the time; and his (brother) Jonah Howe was well acquainted with (the) fact of his service at the time it was performed.
Jon. a Howe
He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state.
Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid.
Jon. a Howe
Before Nathl. Paine Judge of Probate for the County of Worcester
transcripts.extracted_text:
**DECLARATION,** in order to secure the benefit of the Act of Congress, passed June 7, 1832.

# COMMONWEALTH OF MASSACHUSETTS.

**COUNTY OF WORCESTER, SS.**

ON this 14th day of September in the year of our Lord, eighteen hundred and thirty two personally appeared in open Court, before Hon Nathl Paine, Judge of the Court of Probate now sitting Jonathan Howe, a resident of Paxton in the County of Worcester and Commonwealth of Massachusetts, aged seventy years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress, passed June 7th, 1832.

THAT he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated.

That he was born 30 Sept. 1761, in that part of Rutland now Paxton where he has resided ever since.

That in the autumn of 1777, his father, Paul Howe, now deceased, enlisted for seven months, in the Army of the Revolution, & went to Springfield, Mass. At the expiration of one month, after he had been transported to Brookfield, Mass., his above named father, Paul Howe, at his father's request, on account of his ill health took his place as his substitute at said Brookfield, and there performed a term of service of six months in defense of the stores deposited at that place. The only duty performed was to stand sentry, which he fully performed for the above stated term at the expiration of which time he was honorably dismissed.

Officers who had command of the troops stationed at base at Brookfield during that term were Lieut. Peter Davis of Rutland, and Lieut. Freeman of Sturbridge. Silas Chaffin, now of Holden, was with him in the same service during the said term; Levi Hathaway, of North Brookfield, was with him a part of the time; and his brother, Frank Howe, was well acquainted with the fact of his service at the time it was performed.

Jon Howe

He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state.

Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid.

Nathl Paine Judge
Probate Court
of Worcester
Jon a Howe

28 Billingham Street
Somerville, Mass.
May 22, 1935
Re: Identity of Daniel Howe (How) of Tyringham,
Massachusetts, Revolutionary War Soldier.
Bureau of Pensions,
Gentlemen:
It is desired to learn the name or names of one or both of the parents of this Daniel Howe of Tyringham, Mass.
Did this Daniel Howe or his wife receive a pension.
His service record as give in "Massachusetts Soldiers and Sailors in the War of the Revolution," Vol. VIII, p. 329, is as follows:
"How. Daniel, Tyringham (also given Arundel), Order on Maj. Barber, payable to Lieut. John Chadwick: also, Private, Joseph Strebben's Co., Col. Jonathan Brewer's regt; muster Roll Aug.1 1775 enlisted May 12 1775; service, 81 days; also, Company return (probably Oct., 1775); also, order of bounty cost or its equivalent in money dated Prospect Hill, Oct. 26 1775; also, return of men raised for Continental service probably from Capt. Harick's (Herrick's) co; residence, Tyringham; engaged for town of Tyringham; joined Capt. Chadwick's co., Col. Brewer's regt.; term, 3 years; also, list of men mustered between Jan. 20 1777 and June 1, 1778 by Trueman Wheeler, Muster Master for Berkshire Co.; Capt. Stone's co.; also Sergeant, Capt. Mean's co.; Col. Ebeneser Sprout's regt.; Continental Army pay accounts for service from Jan. 1, 1777, to Sept. 14, 1779; reported discharged Sept. 14 1779; also, Capt. John Chadwick's co., Col. Brewer's regt.; returns dated Jan. 22 1778; residence, Arundel; enlisted for town of Tyringham, mustered by Muster Master Wheeler; reported sick at Tyringham."
It is surmised, but no proof has been found, that this Daniel Howe was the son of Daniel and Ann (Bronson) Howe, born 4 Oct. 1741 at Waterbury, Conn. and that his wife's name was Damaris (Dutton) Howe.
Does his pension or other record give any of these data.
Respectfully
[signature of J. Albert Holmes]
J. Albert Holmes

I Jonathan Perkins of North Bridgewater in the County of Plymouth + State of Massachusetts, a soldier of the Revolution, and a pensioner of the United States, under the Act of June 7th, 1832. I am well acquainted with Oliver Howard of said North Bridgewater; that I have known him from our boyhood; that I was attached to a Company of minute men under Captain Josiah Hayden at the time of the alarm in April 1775 when the British marched to Lexington; I marched towards Poxbury with said Company, of which the said Oliver Howard was one; at Dorchester we were ordered to Marchfield, when we were dismissed, + returned to Bridgewater, having been absent three days; Oliver Howard afore said was with me during said three days.
In 1776 or 1777 the British landed at [illegible] a sea shore in Captain David Pachand's Company - was gone two days, when we were dismissed + returned home - Oliver Howard aforesaid, was with us during the two days.
In 1776, I enlisted into Captain Nathan Alolem's Company of Massachusetts militia in a Regiment commanded by Colonels Hall and Johnson, for three months, and marched to Bristol in Rhode Island, and served the full term of three months. The aforesaid Oliver Howard was with me in the same Company during the three months, at the end of which time we were dismissed without a written discharge.
Jonathan Perkins
Commonwealth of Massachusetts
Plymouth County ls
April 3rd 1834. Then personally appeared Jonathan Perkins, and subscribed the foregoing [illegible] and made oath to the truth of the same - and I further certify
that said Jonathan Perkins is a man of truth and veracity.
Before me, Jesse Perkins, Justice of Peace
transcripts.extracted_text:
I Jonathan Perkins of North Bridgewater in the County
of Plymouth & State of Massachusetts, a soldier of the Revolution, and
a pensioner of the United States, under the Act of June 7, 1832:
being of the age of seventy five years, do testify and say, that
I am well acquainted with Oliver Howard of said North
Bridgewater, that I have known him from our boyhood: that
I was attached to a Company of Minute men under
Captain Josiah Hayden at the time of the alarm in April
1775 when the British marched to Lexington; I marched towards
Roxbury with said Company, of which the said Oliver Howard
was one: at Dorchester we were ordered to Marshfield, where
we were dismissed, & returned to Bridgewater, having been
absent three days: Oliver Howard aforesaid was with me during
said three days.

In 1776 or 1777 the British landed at Braintree or
Weymouth, when an alarm was given: I then marched to the
sea shore in Capt. David Packard's Company - was gone two
days, when we were dismissed & returned home - Oliver Howard
aforesaid, was with us during the two days.

In 1776, I enlisted into Capt. Nathan Alden's Company of
Massachusetts militia in a Regiment commanded by Colo:
one E Hall & Johnson, for three months, & marched to Bristol
in Rhode Island, & served the full term of three months.

The aforesaid Oliver Howard was with me in the same
Company during the three months, at the end of which time
we were dismissed without a written discharge.

Jon'a Perkins

Commonwealth of Massachusetts
Plymouth County ss. April 3. 1834. Then personally appeared
Jonathan Perkins, & subscribed the foregoing affidavit, and made
oath to the truth of the same - and I further certify that said Jon'a
Perkins is a man of truth & veracity.

Before me Jesse Perkins Justice of Peace

We Willis Walker a clergyman residing in Union District and Major Thomas Young residing in the same do hereby certify that we are well acquainted with Mordecai Chandler who has subscribed and sworn to the foregoing declaration, that we believe him to be seventy years of age, that he is reputed and believed in the neighborhood where he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution and we concur in that opinion.
Willis Walker
Thomas Young

Jno B Oneall
Pres Judge

And the said court does hereby declare its opinion after the investigation of the matter and after putting the interrogatories prescribed by the War Department, that the above named applicant was a Revolutionary soldier and served as he states— and the said court further certifies that it appears to it that Willis Walker who has subscribed the above certificate is a Clergyman residing in Union District and that Majr Thos Young who has subscribed the same is a credible person and his statements are entitled to credit.
Jno B. ONeall
Pres Judge

I John Rogers, clerk of the Court of Common Pleas and Sessions, do hereby certify that the foregoing contains the original proceeding in the matter of the application of Mordecai Chandler for a pension.
In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand & seal of office this 15th day of October 183[?]
J. Rogers Clk

The State of South Carolina

Know all more by those present that I Samuel Phillips administrator of all all [sic] and singular the rights and credits goods and chattels which were of Mordecai Chandler late of Union District & State aforesaid deceased, a Revolutionary pensioner of the United States under act congress 7th June 1832 at the rate of eighty dollars per annum do make constitute and appoint Jas. A Black Esquire of Columbia South Carolina and State aforesaid my true and lawful attorney for me and in my name place and stead to prosecute against the United States my claim as administrator as aforesaid for the benefit of heirs at law of the said Mordecai Chandler deceased, (who are his now living children) to an increase of pension and arrears of pension up to the day of the death of the said Mordecai Chandler, to examine all papers on file in the pension office of the United States and to file such further evidence record or otherwise as shall already show the right of his said children to an increase of pension on the the yearly amount

State of South Carolina
Union District

On this thirty first day
of January AD eighteen hundred and
fifty seven personally appeared
before me a notary public and
authorized to administer oaths for
general purposes for said District
John H Skelton and George Spencer
citizens and residents of said District who
being duly sworn according to law
deposed and say that they were
well acquainted with Mordecai Chandler
in his lifetime, deceased late of this district
who was a revolutionary pensioner
of the United States:  That they were near
neighbors of his, and from date
of facts within their recollection
are enable to speak positively of the
date of his death which took place
at his residence in this district on
the ___  day of May AD 1846
That he left a widow, who has
since died to wit on or about this
___ day of May AD1852 that
besides his said widow (now deceased)
he left him surviving the following
children viz. Robert Chandler, Samson
Chander, Rosanda Philips wife of
Samuel Philips, Jane Stevens wife
of Chams Stevens, Margaret James
wife of William James who are
all now living as affiants believe
and are the only children and heirs
at law of the said Mordecai Chandler
deceased      And these deponents

Union District

On this thirty first day of January A D Eighteen hundred and fifty seven personally appeared before me a Notary Public and administering to administer oaths for general purposes for said District John B. Stevson and George Spencer citizens and residents of said District who being duly sworn according to law depose and say that they were well acquainted with Mr. Mordecai Chandler in his lifetime, deceased, late of this district who was a revolutionary pensioner of the United States. That they were near neighbors of his and from date of acquaintance with him recollect to have inquired particularly of him as to his death which took place at his residence in this district on the ____ day of May A.D. 1846. That he left a widow who has since died to wit on or about the ____ day of May A.D. 1852. That besides this said widow (now deceased) he left the following surviving children viz. Robert Chandler, Manson Chandler, Rebeccah Philips wife of Samuel Philips, Jane Stevens wife of Chesman Stevens, Margaret James wife of William James who are all now living as affiants believe and are the only children and heirs at law of the said Mordecai Chandler deceased.

South Carolina 
Union District

Mordcai Chandler came personally before me, and deposeth as follows that In order to Explain & make more explicit his application for a pension under the Act of Congress passed the 7th June 1832 –
Saith that in Oct. 1777 he enlisted in Capt DIcksons Company in the Regt. Commanded by Colo Saml Jack of the State of Georgia for two years, being a Regiment of minute men by the authority of the State of Georgia properly organized by the law of that State, marched as set out in my first declaration, and In consequence of Volunteering to go to Florida the Govenor of Georgia then discharged us from our enlistment after having performed our "Tour to "Florida, having served Twelve Months of our two years Term of Enlistment  I again was drafted under Capt Jas. Lyles in the Regiment Commanded by Colo John Lyles and Marched as set out in my first declaration, and served Four months duty & was discharged, I again was drafted the second time 1779. Under Capt. Jas. Lyles & Colo John Lyles and served another tour of four months duty our draft was for but three months but owing to great difficulty my officers prevailed on me to remain one month over our regular Tour,  See my first declaration under Where & When my Service was performed – I again after the fall
of Charleston Volunteered as a refugee under Capt Robuck in Colo Thomas Regiment.  We then Marched to No. Carolina & joined Genl. Sumpter  Clark & Shelby, was in the Engagements Set out ["under" crossed out] in my  first declaration, and after the battle at Musgraves we again retreated to No. Carolina again Where I joined my old regiment under Colo Lyles, and marched back to Newberry Dist So.Car.  where I was taken prisoner while on a Scouting Party having then

in my first declaration,  This [illegible] Served over four years to the best of recollection,  This [illegible] further States that he never followed any Civil [illegible] during his Service in the revolutionary War as Set out was [illegible] called into the Service under & by Competant Authority –
[signed “Mordecai Chandler”]
Sworn to & Subscribed before }        
Me this 8th August 1833. }
[signed "James Rowntree JP”]

I James Rowntree do Certify that Mordecai Chandler who has Sworn to & Subscribed the above affidavit is a respectable old Gentleman & entitled to every credit as a man of Veracity – Given under my hand the

transcripts.extracted_text:
Served nine months, was conveyed to Jail at Ninety
Six So Ca & remained in said Jail four months and
then sent to Charleston & Put on Board of a Prison
ion Ship where I remained two months before I
was exchanged - I again Volunteered under Colo
Harris & performed a Tour of duty in the lower
country of two months, I again joined Capt.
Williams Company as a Volunteer for six months.
I again served four months under Maj. Parsons and
before he quit, I also served three months as a
substitute under Capt. Henry Lyly enrolled before
in my first declarations. This deponent would ever
refer you to the best of recollections, this deponent
further states that he never followed any civil
pursuit during his service in the Revolutionary
War as he was always called out to the
service under & by Competent Authority -

Sworn to & Subscribed before
me this 8th August 1853.

Mordecai Chandler

James Rowntree J.P.

I James Rowntree do Certify that Mordecai Chandler
who has sworn to & subscribed the above affidavit is
a respectable old Gentleman & entitled to every credit
as a man of Veracity. Given under my hand this
8th day of Aug. 1853 -

James Rowntree J.P.

Served nine months, was compelled to Sail at Trinity
for Sail & remained in Sail five months and
then Sent to Charleston & Poleau board of a pris-
on Ship where I remained two months before I
was exchanged - I again Volunteered under Col.
Penis & performed a tour of duty in the lower
country, of two months, I again Joined Capt.
William's Company as a Volunteer for Six months -
I again Served four months under Maj. Pearson not
before Set out, I also Served three months as a
Substitute under Capt. Henry Lyles omitted before
in my first declaration. This deponent Served over
four years to the best of recollection. This deponent
further States that he never followed any Civil
pursuit during his Service in the revolutionary
War as his aid was always called in to the
Service under & by competent authority -

Sworn to & Subscribed before   Mordecai Chandler
me this 8th August 1838.

James Rowntree JP

I James Rowntree do Certify that Mordecai Chandler
who has Sworn & Subscribed the above affidavit is
a respectable old Gentleman & entitled to every credit
as a man of Veracity - Sworn before me this
                                8th day of Aug- 1838 -

                                James Rowntree JP.

District of Union

Given under my hand at Union Court House on the day & year above written.

I John Rogers Clerk of the Court of Union District Certify that J. J. Pratt is a magistrate as above, and that the foregoing certificate purporting to be his, is genuine. In testimony whereof I have hereunto affixed my seal of office & and subscribed my name, this 4th day of Nov. in the year of 1837.

John Rogers Clerk of the Court of Union District.

Unionville SC
April 8, 1857

J. E. Whiting, Esq

Sir,

Your report and instructions of March 28 addressed to Samuel Phillips was by him today handed to me to answer, as I had prepared the papers and proofs without a written power and his attorney.

In behalf of Mr. Phillips, he is not applying for pension for Elizabeth Chandler, but as administrator of Mordecai Chandler. The fact that Mr. Phillips is administrator of Elizabeth Chandler was stated as a collateral fact to establish the other main fact that the children of Mordecai Chandler are entitled to his arrears and increased pension. Will Mr. Morse please re-examine the claim with the view of allowing the claimant arrear of pension and increased pension for the benefit of the children of Mordecai Chandler.

In a short time expect to forward to your office "recorded" evidence to increase the pension of Mordecai Chandler. The rolls at Washington do not show it. You will oblige by sending a report as soon as possible.

The administrator of Mr. Phillips

Columbia So. Ca.
29 June '37

Hon. G. C. Whiting
Commr. Pensions

Dear Sir

I enclose Power of Attorney of Saml. B. Phillips admin. of Estate of Mordecai Chandler U.S. pensioner Act of 7 June 1832 at rate of $80 per year, and also Comptroller's Certificate showing that £828 *"old Currency" was paid him and that 20 Shillings of £1 *"old Currency" was the *pay per day of a private of Cavalry of which Kind of Service there is ample proof among your S. C. pensioners were the Regiments of Robuck as a whole & ["Brandon"  marked out; "Water's" added] as a part.—  But counted at 10.S. *"Old Currency" 1656 days as
*private  of *Infantry.  Now by reference to his declaration you will doubtless see that he *claimed Cavalry Service   Consequently his pension should have been $100 per year & this increase is what his admn. claims for his children & Grandchildren.
Please investigate & report.

Very respectfully
yr. obt. servt.
James A Black Atty.—

*All entries with asterisk were underlined.

Declaration
In order to obtain the benefits of the Acts of Congress 15th May 1828 7th July 1838
State of New York
Oneida County:
On this 21st day of October in the year of our Lord One thousand eight hundred and fifty two, personally appeared before the Honorable Ralph McIntosh Special Surrogate and Justice of a Court of Record in and for the County of Oneida and State of New York aforesaid Mary House aged eighty 80 years, a resident of Oneida in the County of Oneida, who being duly sworn according to law, doth upon her oath makes the following declaration in order to obtain she benefits of the provisions made by the Act of Congress passed 15th May 1828 entitled Pension granted to all the officers who served to the end of the Revolutionary War in the Continental Army also the Act of Congress passed July 7th 1838 entitled an Act granting half pay and pensions to certain widow and the other acts of Congress extending said act that she is the widow of John House deceased who was a private in the Revolutionary War in Company Commanded first by Captain Andrew Frink and afterwords and near the later part of said war by Captain Sytez in the first Military Regiment of the original Five Regiments of the New York troops in the Continental Line Commanded by Colonel Goose Van Schaicks, that he enlisted some time in about the month of January or February in the year of our lord seventeen

transcripts.original_text:
Commonwealth of Massachusetts.
County of Worcester, ss.
ON this sixth day of September in the year of our Lord, eighteen hundred and thirty two personally appeared in open Court, before Hon. Nathl Paine, Judge of that Court of Probate now sitting Jonathan Howe, a resident of Paxton, in the County of Worcester, and Commonwealth of Massachusetts, aged seventy years, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress, passed June 7th, 1832.
THAT he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated.
That he was born 30 Sept. 1761, in that part of Rutland, now Paxton, where he has resided ever since.
That in the autumn of 1777, his father, Paul Howe, now deceased, enlisted for seven months in this (cause) of the Revolution, & went to Springfield, Mass. at the expiration of one month. After he had been transferred to Brookfield, Mass. he, the abovenamed Jonathan Howe, at his father's request, on account of his ill health, took his place as his substitute at said Brookfield, and there performed a term of service of six months, in (defense) of (the) military (stores) deposited at that place. The only duty performed was to stand sentry, which he faithfully performed for the above stated term, at the expiration of which time he was honorably dismissed. The officers who had command of the troops stationed at said Brookfield during that term, were Lieut. Peter Davis of Rutland, and Lieut. Freeman, of Sturbridge. Tilly Chaffin, now of Holden, was with him in the same service during (the) said term; Levi Hathaway, of North Brookfield, was with him a part of the time; and his (brother) Jonah Howe was well acquainted with (the) fact of his service at the time it was performed.
Jon. a Howe
He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declares that his name is not on the pension roll of the agency of any state.
Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid.
Jon. a Howe
Before Nathl. Paine Judge of Probate for the County of Worcester

28 Billingham Street
Somerville, Mass.
May 22, 1935
Re: Identity of Daniel Howe (How) of Tyringham,
Massachusetts, Revolutionary War Soldier.
Bureau of Pensions,
Gentlemen:
It is desired to learn the name or names of one or both of the parents of this Daniel Howe of Tyringham, Mass.
Did this Daniel Howe or his wife receive a pension.
His service record as give in "Massachusetts Soldiers and Sailors in the War of the Revolution," Vol. VIII, p. 329, is as follows:
"How. Daniel, Tyringham (also given Arundel), Order on Maj. Barber, payable to Lieut. John Chadwick: also, Private, Joseph Strebben's Co., Col. Jonathan Brewer's regt; muster Roll Aug.1 1775 enlisted May 12 1775; service, 81 days; also, Company return (probably Oct., 1775); also, order of bounty cost or its equivalent in money dated Prospect Hill, Oct. 26 1775; also, return of men raised for Continental service probably from Capt. Harick's (Herrick's) co; residence, Tyringham; engaged for town of Tyringham; joined Capt. Chadwick's co., Col. Brewer's regt.; term, 3 years; also, list of men mustered between Jan. 20 1777 and June 1, 1778 by Trueman Wheeler, Muster Master for Berkshire Co.; Capt. Stone's co.; also Sergeant, Capt. Mean's co.; Col. Ebeneser Sprout's regt.; Continental Army pay accounts for service from Jan. 1, 1777, to Sept. 14, 1779; reported discharged Sept. 14 1779; also, Capt. John Chadwick's co., Col. Brewer's regt.; returns dated Jan. 22 1778; residence, Arundel; enlisted for town of Tyringham, mustered by Muster Master Wheeler; reported sick at Tyringham."
It is surmised, but no proof has been found, that this Daniel Howe was the son of Daniel and Ann (Bronson) Howe, born 4 Oct. 1741 at Waterbury, Conn. and that his wife's name was Damaris (Dutton) Howe.
Does his pension or other record give any of these data.
Respectfully
[signature of J. Albert Holmes]
J. Albert Holmes

I Jonathan Perkins of North Bridgewater in the County of Plymouth + State of Massachusetts, a soldier of the Revolution, and a pensioner of the United States, under the Act of June 7th, 1832. I am well acquainted with Oliver Howard of said North Bridgewater; that I have known him from our boyhood; that I was attached to a Company of minute men under Captain Josiah Hayden at the time of the alarm in April 1775 when the British marched to Lexington; I marched towards Poxbury with said Company, of which the said Oliver Howard was one; at Dorchester we were ordered to Marchfield, when we were dismissed, + returned to Bridgewater, having been absent three days; Oliver Howard afore said was with me during said three days.
In 1776 or 1777 the British landed at [illegible] a sea shore in Captain David Pachand's Company - was gone two days, when we were dismissed + returned home - Oliver Howard aforesaid, was with us during the two days.
In 1776, I enlisted into Captain Nathan Alolem's Company of Massachusetts militia in a Regiment commanded by Colonels Hall and Johnson, for three months, and marched to Bristol in Rhode Island, and served the full term of three months. The aforesaid Oliver Howard was with me in the same Company during the three months, at the end of which time we were dismissed without a written discharge.
Jonathan Perkins
Commonwealth of Massachusetts
Plymouth County ls
April 3rd 1834. Then personally appeared Jonathan Perkins, and subscribed the foregoing [illegible] and made oath to the truth of the same - and I further certify
that said Jonathan Perkins is a man of truth and veracity.
Before me, Jesse Perkins, Justice of Peace

South Carolina 
Union District

Mordcai Chandler came personally before me, and deposeth as follows that In order to Explain & make more explicit his application for a pension under the Act of Congress passed the 7th June 1832 –
Saith that in Oct. 1777 he enlisted in Capt DIcksons Company in the Regt. Commanded by Colo Saml Jack of the State of Georgia for two years, being a Regiment of minute men by the authority of the State of Georgia properly organized by the law of that State, marched as set out in my first declaration, and In consequence of Volunteering to go to Florida the Govenor of Georgia then discharged us from our enlistment after having performed our "Tour to "Florida, having served Twelve Months of our two years Term of Enlistment  I again was drafted under Capt Jas. Lyles in the Regiment Commanded by Colo John Lyles and Marched as set out in my first declaration, and served Four months duty & was discharged, I again was drafted the second time 1779. Under Capt. Jas. Unionville SC
April 8—1857

G C Whiting Esqr

Sir

Your report and instructions of March 28 addressed to Samul Phillips, was by him today handed to me to answer.  as I had proposed the papers, and though without a written power am his attorney

You have mistaken the object of Mr Phillips; he is not applying for pension, for Elizabeth Chandler, but as administrator of Mordecai Chandler:  In fact that Mr. Phillips is administrator of *Elizabeth Chandler was stated as a collateral *fact to establish the other main fact that the children of Mordecai Chandler are entitled to his arrears and *increased Pension you will therefore please re examine [sic] the claim with the view of allowing the claimant arrears  of pension and increased pension for the benefit of the children of Mordecai Chandler—

In a short time, I expect to forward to your office "recorded" evidence to increase the pension of Mordecai Chandler if the Rolls at Washington do no show it [sic]  You will oblige by sending a report as soon as possible

The declaration of Mr. Phillips

Columbia So. Ca.
29 June '37

Hon. G. C. Whiting
Commr. Pensions

Dear Sir

I enclose Power of Attorney of Saml. B. Phillips admin. of Estate of Mordecai Chandler U.S. pensioner Act of 7 June 1832 at rate of $80 per year, and also Comptroller's Certificate showing that £828 *"old Currency" was paid him and that 20 Shillings of £1 *"old Currency" was the *pay per day of a private of Cavalry of which Kind of Service there is ample proof among your S. C. pensioners were the Regiments of Robuck as a whole & ["Brandon"  marked out; "Water's" added] as a part.—  But counted at 10.S. *"Old Currency" 1656 days as
*private  of *Infantry.  Now by reference to his declaration you will doubtless see that he *claimed Cavalry Service   Consequently his pension should have been $100 per year & this increase is what his admn. claims for his children & Grandchildren.
Please investigate & report.

Very respectfully
yr. obt. servt.
James A Black Atty.—

*All entries with asterisk were underlined.
